docs.title: What is an Ontology?
docs.text: An ontology is a formal representation of knowledge that specifies concepts, relationships, and properties within a specific domain, for example the industrial sector. It provides a shared understanding and common vocabulary for individuals and systems, facilitating knowledge sharing, interoperability, and reasoning.

docs.title: Knowledge Sharing
docs.text: Ontologies encourage the creation of a shared understanding of some domain through a formal agreement between communities on the existence and definitions of concepts and relationships.

docs.title: Data Integration
docs.text: Ontologies enhance data interoperability by establishing a common framework for different systems to understand and exchange information. (ontology-based data access)

docs.title: AI and Machine Learning
docs.text:

docs.title: Getting Started with Ontologies
docs.text: The books "A Semantic Web Primer" by Grigoris Antoniou and Frank van Harmelen and "Semantic Web for the Working Ontologist" by Dean Allemang and James Hendler are both comprehensive guides to getting started with ontologies within the semantic web. The book “An Introduction to Ontology Engineering” by Maria Keet is another great resource that focuses more on the development of ontologies.

docs.title: Common Ontologies
docs.text: IndustryPortal is an ontology repository hosting over 100 ontologies from the industrial domain. Below 5 of the more common enterprise or industrial ontologie are listed.

docs.title: SKOS (Simple Knowledge Organisation System)
docs.text: Common data model for sharing and linking knowledge organisation systems via the Semantic Web.

docs.title: BFO (Basic Formal Ontology)
docs.text: Small, upper level ontology that is designed for use in supporting information retrieval, analysis and integration in scientific and other domains

docs.title: GIST Ontology
docs.text: Minimalist upper ontology for the enterprise, designed to provide the maximum coverage of typical business concepts with the fewest number of primitives and the least amount of ambiguity.

docs.title: IOF Core Ontology
docs.text: Mid-level ontology that resides at the top of the suite of ontologies by the Industrial Ontologies Foundary (IOF).

docs.title: Industrial Data Ontology (IDO)
docs.text: Upper ontology for industrial data by PCA.

docs.title: Industrial Ontologies Foundry (IOF)
docs.text: Group working to create a suite of interoperable ontologies that serve as a foundation for data and information interoperability in all areas of manufacturing.

docs.title: OntoCommons
docs.text: European group dedicated to the standardisation of data documentation across all domains related to materials and manufacturing.

docs.title: POSC Caesar Association (PCA)
docs.text: Non-profit global-standardization member organisation promoting the development of open, standards-based specifications for the energy industry.
